text:
Does anyone know of a package that could be used to make Chord Diagrams?
<https://observablehq.com/@d3/chord-dependency-diagram?collection=@d3/d3-chord>

Alternatively - is there a recommended binding to d3 in julia? I found a couple packages on GitHub, but they haven't been updated in quite some time, so I'm wondering if they've been superseded.

attachments.title: Chord Dependency Diagram
attachments.text: This chord diagram shows dependencies among a software class hierarchy. Although it does not reveal class-level detail, as hierarchical edge bundling does, it conveys the total number of imports between and within packages. Note, for example, that the util package does not import anything besides itself.

elements.text: Does anyone know of a package that could be used to make Chord Diagrams?
Alternatively - is there a recommended binding to d3 in julia? I found a couple packages on GitHub, but they haven't been updated in quite some time, so I'm wondering if they've been superseded.

text: You should check out Luxor.jl <@UP0P065ME> and also this awesome blog post by <@U7K185TUN> <https://opensourc.es/blog/visualizing-the-irrational-vote/>

attachments.title: Pi vs Tau
attachments.text: Is Pi better or Tau? I'm always for pie. Mathematical reasons are boring. Your visual cortex should decide.

elements.text: and also this awesome blog post by

text:
Thanks <@US64J0NPQ>! Definitely a beautiful plot in that post. Sounds like it would be a bit manual to get it drawn - at least in this case, I will eventually need to port the analysis to JS to embed on a webpage, and was hoping there might be pre-built solution to get an example while sticking to Julia. If not, I think I might hop over to JS to do the low-level plotting from the start.

Thanks for the suggestion, though! If I had more time I would love to build out a function in Julia - maybe after I got a handle on the plot construct I can build a recipe.

elements.text:
! Definitely a beautiful plot in that post. Sounds like it would be a bit manual to get it drawn - at least in this case, I will eventually need to port the analysis to JS to embed on a webpage, and was hoping there might be pre-built solution to get an example while sticking to Julia. If not, I think I might hop over to JS to do the low-level plotting from the start.

Thanks for the suggestion, though! If I had more time I would love to build out a function in Julia - maybe after I got a handle on the plot construct I can build a recipe.
